Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The patient most likely has acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis, which is characterized by a rapid onset of a pustular rash following a medication exposure in a patient without a history of pustular psoriasis. Patients present with fever and erythema, and then develop myriad dense non-folliculocentric pustules, primarily in skin folds and on the trunk. The onset of the rash may be as soon as 1 day after exposure to the medication and up to a few days at most. Eighty percent of cases are caused by antibiotics.
